Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 28 Student Book. The title of this story is "Bella's Search.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Bella's Search. Look at the picture and tell what you think the girl in the background is doing.

Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: traits. Traits are a person, animal, or object’s characteristics or features. The puppy has many of the same traits as its mother. What traits do you admire, or really like, in a person?
Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

A possessive noun is a noun that shows ownership. That means that the person, place, or thing, has something. The possessive form of a singular noun is created by adding "apostrophe s" to the end. If a plural noun end with an s, the possessive form is created by only adding an apostrophe.

audio.notes: <visual: show the word card "cats" and the word card "cats'">

A possessive noun is a noun that shows ownership. That means that the person, place, or thing, has something. The possessive form of a singular noun is created by adding "apostrophe s" to the end. If a plural noun end with an s, the possessive form is created by only adding an apostrophe.

audio.transcription: Listen as I read two other words: "teachers" <pause> "teachers' " "teachers" with an apostrophe at the end is the possessive form of the plural noun cats. Adding an apostrophe to the end of a plural noun that ends with s does not change how you say the word.
